title: Developmental Domain 3: Language Development, Communication, and Literacy
subject: Early Learning Guidelines: Birth to Age 3 (2012-)

document.title: Illinois Early Learning Guidelines For Children Birth to Age Three

2C4700F541064F58A5CD61CC0EE5662C.description:
Expresses what happens next when reading a familiar book with
a caregiver, e.g., uses gestures, words, and/or sounds

2D2BD38B417C4E6C9FFB804881564440.description:
Scribbles in a more orderly fashion and begins to name what he
or she has drawn

46CE6C7A99614D9A9FAE5F4D6EAAF160.description: Recites parts of a book from memory

80CC690CBD784106A12194BF6CA6A676.description:
Participates in early literacy activities independently, e.g., sits in
a reading nook and browses through the pages

5840C5608ED948C6905B789BE5A034B2.description:
Imitates adult role when engages with printed materials, e.g.,
pretends to read a book or newspaper to stuffed animals or dolls

773FB7614457469B952E7715BB609F58.description:
Â Identifies a favorite book and signals familiar others to read with
him or her, e.g., brings the book over, or points and gestures

0C13D3261EAE4C7D904890B28BBA80A9.description:
Begins to anticipate what may happen next in a familiar book,
e.g., generates sounds and movements and/or uses words for
pictures

5C999D55409D4D259E193B31EE868DDC.description: Repeats familiar words in a book when being read to

71471E16CF45420089360AC7F84B91F8.description: Points to familiar pictures and actions in books

0FE63DBA49294CB2806134B5F3F1B595.description: Turns the pages of a board book, one by one

FA5A207D071643D0BAF9EDFF4B662501.description:
Grasps objects and attempts to scribble, e.g., makes a slight
mark with a crayon on a piece of paper

2BEF321F4E39432DA0295D0A0E7A9C26.description:
Increases ability to focus for longer periods of time on printed
materials

AA54825EDCBF4F75847C4C6B394AC53C.description:
Imitates gestures and sounds during activities, e.g., hand actions
during singing, babbles as caregiver reads book

0DDDE3121EBC46E9A372DDA62E9F78E4.description:
Initiates literacy activities, e.g., gestures toward a book or
attempts to turn pages of a paper book or magazine

AC44440AC1084FCFB82C1C8266DD4109.description:
Points to pictures in a book and reacts, e.g., smiles when sees a
picture of a dog

CAC2EC573C2A4752AB1B81AA338A9DB1.description:
Focuses attention while looking at printed materials for brief
periods of time

7C2F28027BB146CE8823FA1C6150AFAB.description: Points or makes sounds while looking at picture books

74CEDA80ECEA4013B59C212D0822CD4E.description:
Uses hands to manipulate printed materials, e.g., attempts to
turn pages of a board book, grasps objects in hands

C3B59A967F334D4EB73A12268851CD65.description:
Uses multiple senses to explore books, e.g., explores books with
different textures

D4B6FDEA676D4023AC114B0A7FA6884E.description: Reaches out to grasp and mouth books

9D982533B65342F386C9302EF739CC2C.description:
Shows awareness of printed materials, e.g., stares at a picture in
a book

DA4DF91AB70947FAAF65B62AEACFD012.description: Children demonstrate interest in and comprehension of printed materials.

7F4238F67734437E950A6DB826766704.description: Has a vocabulary of more than 300 words

60E147C2D052498180F4DE74DE7CA7CD.description: Uses simple sentences, e.g., âI want the yellow cupâ

F4605138660B41D99F97E36BC3640D29.description: Uses adjectives in speech, e.g., âblue carâ

99D77DF414934702A332E21CEE2E54FF.description:
Makes mistakes, which signal that he or she is working out
complex grammar rules

EDC4384CB08C48C7B1CEBFD90B937CFE.description:
Begins to use pronouns and prepositions, e.g., âHe took my toyâ
and âon the tableâÂ

27AA287CC9D94AA9BD75B6023A706FAF.description: Speaks in three-word utterances, e.g., âI want ballâ

0966EE4EC3E54895853A507E92A402B6.description:
Begins to use telegraphic speech , consisting of phrases with
words left out, e.g., âbaby sleepâ for âThe baby is sleepingâ

9049B6E65E0C4FE1BE9CBB21044E987A.description: Has a vocabulary of approximately 80 words

2EABAF96356F4C18BFB6E6024BA358E8.description: Uses more words than gestures when speaking

2B52180218F146679588C419F215BA2A.description: Uses one word to convey a message, e.g., âmilkâ for âI want milkâÂ

4B4F1E5B72934295A1942116A142CFF4.description: Names a few familiar objects in his/her environment

D0082F17704345B29B7ED4552DA4A116.description:
Utters first words; these words are for familiar objects and
people, e.g., âmama,â âbottleâ

7BE5433DFABD4A6AA3F01CDA088024FA.description:
Uses nonverbal communication to express ideas, e.g., waves
bye-bye, signs âmoreâ when eating

4E6DD375998A4C04B543F48C28F1076A.description: Babbles using the sounds of the home languageÂ

9EED87A0B68D459A9F1148C59765F730.description: Begins to point to objects in his/her environment

1D8C1AE31BA24C908D08E74859AF9F60.description:
Babbles and experiments with all types of sounds (two-lip
sounds: âp,â âb,â âmâ)Â

2066502EFF81484E870D8625C8BD3863.description: Coos and uses physical movements to engage familiar others

C737291772DD4812B8DD9F64BAA183D9.description: Uses smiles and other facial expressions to initiate social contact

FE4EC08C10904498B0829F37BC89D177.description: Cries to signal hunger, pain, or distress

89AA85B85D57454386E3DF6726213E5E.description: Children demonstrate the ability to understand and convey thoughts through both nonverbal and verbal expression.

7D8B13DDA5BF4421ABE7DA6D8FE1D04F.description:
Responds verbally and/or nonverbally to comments or questions
while engaged in conversations with both peers and adults

5AF97549CCAA45C5BD9AA9BB9988DFF3.description:
Understands simple sentences or directions with prepositions,
e.g., âPut cup in sinkâ

41DD0372CE90463EB6EECB90B92F06E9.description:
Demonstrates understanding of a story by reacting with sounds,
facial expressions, and physical movement, e.g., laughing, widening eyes, or clapping

31AAEE8864C1449FBFB792D6AA2F24C5.description:
Comprehends compound statements and can follow multi-step
directions

21DA9B59DE73410D9CD142753AD92B8B.description: Names most objects and people in a familiar environment

495638D709FE4F8B84BC3AA85C8EBCC2.description: Responds to personal pronouns, e.g., me, her, him

841123B0234B420A8ECF7CF7109938DB.description: Points to body parts when prompted

C58CB89487F14EE3AEB1015C9B364CC6.description:
Demonstrates understanding of familiar words or phrases by
responding appropriately, e.g., sits in chair after hearing it is
snack time

F2889BE505DB4899AAC9658B471C452A.description:
Understands simple commands and questions and can follow
two-step requests with the support of gestures and prompting

5C9FE7ACB45F4CF8ABCC1536E75E1823.description:
Recognizes and demonstrates understanding of familiar pictures,
people, and objects, e.g., says âmamaâ while pointing to mother

BBC7D5AF63EA4DE7940D373E3D073EB1.description: Understands approximately 100 words relevant to their experiences and cultural context

253C4BD71EE8479E9E85FCCCA9036325.description:
Responds appropriately to familiar words, e.g., hears the words
âso big,â and puts arms in airÂ

0CC1C51630844B49865E7BDDE89B4DED.description: Follows a one-step, simple request when a gesture is used

337329DB5F774B8FADF6D0A99D540B19.description:
Engages in joint attention with a caregiver, e.g., joins in looking
at the same object or shifts gaze to where someone is pointing

5B6DBBFEA3A34161840FBD34C5177CE1.description:
Responds to gestures, e.g., waves hello after a familiar person
waves to him or herÂ

616CC15EB8444E8B9BDA934375417663.description:
Looks or turns toward the familiar person who says his or her
name

6627EF0CCDF642DBA8AEAEB47F4126AC.description:
Calms down when crying after hearing a soothing and familiar
voice or receiving physical reassurance, e.g., a hug or gentle
pats on back

FDCDA7354D6049FE863042CF93502ADC.description:
Responds to sounds found in the environment, e.g., cries if
hears a loud bang, will turn toward a familiar voice

B9A5D630F8104B98877CAA6B8A6DF63C.description: Children demonstrate the ability to comprehend both verbal and nonverbal communication.

43BCC9C41E314504B999AC28653B1A58.description:
Initiates and engages others using meaningful objects or ideas,
e.g., points out his/her artwork or favorite toy to a caregiver to
begin conversingÂ

BF1633B678834F0491E3320933FFA3F2.description:
Uses âwâ questions to initiate and expand conversations, e.g.,
âwho,â âwhat,â âwhyâÂ

4EA5BFD4F90D4847BB1C7C7EB2F5E8AE.description: Communicates related ideas when in interactions with others

BC03E38678974BC486C0E0CB85697496.description:
Uses repetition to maintain the conversation and obtain
responses from familiar others

3EBFC2472EAD4DCB9C629514E54C541B.description:
Begins to make formal requests or responses based on his or her
context and culture

F117C961B73D4871B374930ED9CCBF41.description: Responds verbally to an adultâs questions or comments

9CAB3489FA8143DAB77C32E7B2326556.description:
Demonstrates an understanding of turn-taking in conversations,
e.g., asks and answers simple questions

0D5E18D8BA304B98A98C8B7555370C5D.description:
Pays attention to the person communicating for a brief period of
time

F6895B28960D41E28AD8337E7384FD89.description:
Connects gestures and/or sounds to comment about a familiar
object, e.g., makes a crying sound after the caregiver hugs a
baby doll and says, âHush, babyâ

10F77ACFE37E4080ABCC6FAA3AFFA77D.description:
Initiates and engages in social interaction with simple words and
actions

04DFCF95A18C46CCAA502892970F30D0.description:
Engages in short back-and-forth interactions with familiar
others using verbal and nonverbal communication, e.g., says or
signs âmoreâ after each time a caregiver completes an action the
child is enjoying

572F860242A74F22AA8C9868892F4DDD.description:
Participates in simple back-and-forth communication, using
words and/or gestures

4748C6294AA14156A51BC9B6172F44C7.description:
Uses facial expressions, vocalizations, and gestures to initiate
interactions with others

7514E9CFCA3F4864BE9668D69749A9DF.description:
Responds with âyesâ or âno,â using sounds, words, and/or
gestures to answer simple questions

A62E55F4FFCF485B8C1B54081B8588A9.description:
Demonstrates understanding of a familiar sound or word, e.g.,
looks toward a caregiver after hearing name

6C8C9F8F495E42F5BC56A2F0F8717DD7.description: Communicates and responds by grunting, nodding, and pointing

11C09E65A0AD425BA156762199E19EF3.description:
Participates in back-and-forth communication, e.g., babbles back
and forth and/or plays peek-a-boo with caregiver

BAF92DC8A8384BE181C11F9F71B961DA.description:
Smiles and uses other facial expressions to initiate interactions
with caregiver

D0714BD10C054879A5961894C99FC916.description:
Attempts to engage in early forms of turn-taking with caregiver,
e.g., coos and stares at caregiver

D4384198633C457CA009EE06B258F4E6.description:
Uses sounds, cries, facial expressions, and body language to
convey needs

1BE00625315349A1AF90ABAD66F083E9.description: Children demonstrate the ability to engage with and maintain communication with others.
